required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Furosemide on Confirmation of Ureteral Patency During Routine Cystoscopy
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Controlled Trial Evaluating Effect of Furosemide on Confirmation of Ureteral Patency During Routine Cystoscopy

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates if administration of IV furosemide leads to expedited confirmation of ureteral patency when compared to placebo (IV saline) in routine cystoscopy performed after urogynecologic surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
Cystoscopy is performed routinely after urogynecologic surgery to ensure there was no injury to the urinary tract (urethra, bladder, or ureters). In order to confirm that no damage occurred to the ureters, a jet of urine must be visualized from each ureteral opening.
The time it takes to confirm this ureteral patency is variable and some sources suggest using furosemide to decrease the time it takes to see these jets. This study will evaluate what effect, if any, this medicine has on time to confirming ureteral patency.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: time to confirmation of ureteral patency in seconds

secondary_outcome.time_frame: immediately post operative (1-3 days post operatively)

arm_group.description: furosemide 10mg (1mL) IV push for one dose
normal saline 1mL IV push for one dose

intervention.description: Normal saline given intraoperatively as placebo

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Undergoing any urogynecologic surgery
- No allergy or contraindication to receiving furosemide
- Normal Creatinine/glomerular filtration rate
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to consent, including if non English speaking
- Allergy or contraindication to receiving furosemide
- Intraoperative injury to the lower urinary tract
